data.title: The Risks of Boba
data.statement:
You are drinking boba, but you don't want to choke on any of the tapioca pearls. To not choke, the size of the tapioca ball cluster needs to be less than or equal to the straw's diameter. 
Since there are various types of boba straws, the shops have decided to always make the straw's diameter the average of the highest cluster of tapioca pearls in ALL OF THE DRINK, the highest cluster REVERSED, and the lowest cluster in ALL OF THE DRINK (not every layer). If this number is a decimal, you should round it up ALWAYS, just to be careful. All clusters greater than this number will make you choke.

For example:
3
6 10 43
8 45 12 7 23
32 11 28 56

The first number in the input is how many layers are there in total, so we ignore that number when trying to find the smallest and largest in the sequence.
Since 6 is the smallest in this sequence and  56 is the largest, the straw's diameter would be 6+56+65 (the largest reversed) /3, which would equal 42.3, which would always ROUND UP to 43.
After this, all numbers for each layer are checked to see if they are all under 43. If even just one number in the sequence would be over 43, you would choke on the layer. 

So the output would be:
SIP
CHOKE
CHOKE

testCases.title: One layer with a lot of clusters
One layer with too many clusters

data.stubGenerator:
read n:int
loop n read layer:string(1024)
write CHOKE or SIP
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1>> -  An integer [[n]] for the number of layers in the boba.
<<Next [[n]] lines>> - Each line contains space-separated integers that represent the amount of tapioca pearls per cluster.
data.outputDescription: <<[[n]] lines>> - Each line is either {{CHOKE}} or {{SIP}}. If any cluster in the layer will make you choke, return {{CHOKE}}. Else, return {{SIP}}.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

You are drinking boba, but you don't want to choke on any of the tapioca pearls. To not choke, the size of the tapioca ball cluster needs to be less than or equal to the straw's diameter.
Since there are various types of boba straws, the shops have decided to always make the straw's diameter the average of the highest cluster of tapioca pearls in ALL OF THE DRINK, the highest cluster REVERSED, and the lowest cluster in ALL OF THE DRINK (not every layer). If this number is a decimal, you should round it up ALWAYS, just to be careful. All clusters greater than this number will make you choke.

For example:
3
6 10 43
8 45 12 7 23
32 11 28 56

The first number in the input is how many layers are there in total, so we ignore that number when trying to find the smallest and largest in the sequence.
Since 6 is the smallest in this sequence and 56 is the largest, the straw's diameter would be 6+56+65 (the largest reversed) /3, which would equal 42.3, which would always ROUND UP to 43.
After this, all numbers for each layer are checked to see if they are all under 43. If even just one number in the sequence would be over 43, you would choke on the layer.

So the output would be:
SIP
CHOKE
CHOKE
Input
Line 1 - An integer n for the number of layers in the boba.
Next n lines - Each line contains space-separated integers that represent the amount of tapioca pearls per cluster.
Output
n lines - Each line is either CHOKE or SIP. If any cluster in the layer will make you choke, return CHOKE. Else, return SIP.
Constraints
Example
Input
4
2 7 3
2 1
5 3 4
1 3 8
Output
CHOKE
SIP
SIP
CHOKE
